study.title: Incidence, bacteriological profile and predictors of surgical site infections following limb amputation at Bugando medical centre and Sekou toure referral regional hospital, Mwanza, Tanzania
study.journal: Journal of Orthopaedic Surgery and Research

design.inclusion_criteria_text: All consenting patients who underwent limb amputation at Bugando Medical Centre (BMC) and Sekou Toure Regional Referral Hospital (SRRH) between March and July 2024.
design.exclusion_criteria_text: Patients who previously undergone amputation in other healthcare facilities who were referred for stump revisions were excluded.

country_specific_sites: Sekou Toure Regional Referral Hospital (SRRH), Mwanza

eligibility.population: All consenting patients undergoing limb amputation at BMC and SRRH between March and July 2024.
eligibility.intervention: Standard care limb amputation, with prophylactic antibiotics commonly third and fourth generation cephalosporins.

populations.description: All patients undergoing limb amputation at BMC and SRRH during study period.
populations.comorbidities_key: HIV=1, Diabetes Mellitus=23, Hypertension=4, Malignancy=7, Osteomyelitis=2, Peripheral artery disease=13, Trauma=8; 47.5% had comorbidity; 4.2% smokers; 45.8% underweight

provenance.section_heading: Table 1 Socio-demographic and clinical characteristic of study participants
provenance.text_snippet: A total of 120 patients were included in the study. The median [IQR] age was 58[43.5–66.5] years.

definitions.resistance_definition_text: Antimicrobial susceptibility of isolates was determined using disk diffusion method according to Clinical Laboratory Standard Institute.
definitions.outcome_definitions_text: SSI defined as per CDC criteria; superficial and deep SSI definitions provided. No explicit definitions for mortality, LOS, readmission, or cost.

lab_methods.specimen_collection_method: Two pus swabs obtained from infected surgical wound by sterile cotton swabs, transported in Stuart transport media to laboratory within an hour.
lab_methods.culture_method: Specimens inoculated on Blood agar and MacConkey agar, incubated aerobically for 24–48 h.
lab_methods.organism_identification_method: Conventional physiological and biochemical methods (gram stain, catalase, coagulase, hemolytic activity, hippurate hydrolysis, CAMP test, colony morphology, TSI, indole, motility, citrate, urease, H2S production).
lab_methods.lab_capacity_notes: Anaerobic culture not performed; may underestimate bacteria patterns and culture yield.

ssi_incidence.notes: Incidence of SSI within 30 days following major amputations.

provenance.text_snippet: Out of 120 enrolled and followed patients, 36 developed SSI, therefore the overall incidence of SSI within 3 months of amputation was 30.0% (95% CI 21.8–38).

codes.summary: Study highlights need to improve infection prevention and control programs in hospitals.

evidence_quotes.quote: This study has demonstrated an increased trend of SSI amongst patients who underwent limb amputation underscoring the need to improve infection prevention and control (IPC) programs in these hospitals.

codes.summary: Recommendation to strengthen antimicrobial stewardship and IPC programs to control MDR Gram-negative bacteria.

evidence_quotes.quote: The observed predominance of multi drug resistant (MDR) Gram negative bacteria causing SSI requires strengthening of antimicrobial stewardship and IPC programs in these hospitals and other hospitals in low- and middle-income countries to control emergence and spread of MDR Enterobacterales which have been classified by WHO as critical priority pathogens.
